thread.title: Teens Wearing Leggings Barred From United Airlines Flight
thread.title_full: Teens Wearing Leggings Barred From United Airlines Flight

author: CBS Pittsburgh
title: Teens Wearing Leggings Barred From United Airlines Flight
text:
Teens Wearing Leggings Barred From United Airlines Flight March 26, 2017 6:51 PM Filed Under: United Airlines CHICAGO, IL - SEPTEMBER 19: United Airlines jets sit at gates at O'Hare International Airport on September 19, 2014 in Chicago, Illinois. In 2013, 67 million passengers passed through O'Hare, another 20 million passed through Chicago's Midway Airport, and the two airports combined moved more than 1.4 million tons of air cargo. (Photo by Scott Olson/Getty Images) 
DENVER (AP/KDKA) – Two teenage girls were barred by a gate agent from boarding a United Airlines flight from Denver to Minneapolis because they were wearing leggings. 
United spokesman Jonathan Guerin said the girls were not allowed onto the Sunday morning flight because they were traveling under an employee travel pass that includes a dress code. 
That dress code bars pass travelers from wearing spandex or lycra pants such as leggings. Guerin says the teenagers agreed to change their clothing and take a later flight. 
Stay Up To Date, Follow KDKA On Twitter 
The airline’s actions sparked a backlash on Twitter. Activist Shannon Watts of Denver tweeted that she witnessed Sunday’s events and questioned United’s decision to police women’s clothing. 
United tweeted in response: “In our Contract of Carriage, Rule 21, we do have the right to refuse transport for passengers who are barefoot or not properly clothed.” The airline added a link for more details on its policies and indicated that it was up to the gate agent to determine if a passenger is “properly clothed.” @shannonrwatts In our Contract of Carriage, Rule 21, we do have the right to refuse transport for passengers who … https://t.co/52kRVgaCyb 
— United (@united) March 26, 2017 
Several other people took to social media to weigh in on the rule. @shannonrwatts Hey, @united , you know how this ends, right? Images of women in leggings tagging you on social as they fly your competition.
